metadata.title: A Nitrogen-doped Nano Carbon Dodecahedron with Co@Co3O4 Implants as Bi-functional Electrocatalyst for Efficient Overall Water Splitting

sections.text:
This is an Accepted Manuscript, which has been through the Royal Society of Chemistry peer review process and has been accepted for publication.
Accepted Manuscripts are published online shortly after acceptance, before technical editing, formatting and proof reading. Using this free service, authors can make their results available to the community, in citable form, before we publish the edited article. We will replace this Accepted Manuscript with the edited and formatted Advance Article as soon as it is available.
You can find more information about Accepted Manuscripts in the author guidelines.
Please note that technical editing may introduce minor changes to the text and/or graphics, which may alter content. The journal’s standard Terms & Conditions and the ethical guidelines, outlined in our author and reviewer resource centre, still apply. In no event shall the Royal Society of Chemistry be held responsible for any errors or omissions in this Accepted Manuscript or any consequences arising from the use of any information it contains.

COMMUNICATION

DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x
www.rsc.org/
A Nitrogen-doped Nano Carbon Dodecahedron with Co@Co3O4 Implants as Bi-functional Electrocatalyst for Efficient Overall Water Splitting Chengdong Bai, Shanshan Wei, Dingrong Deng, Xiaodong Lin, Mingsen Zheng* and Quanfeng Dong*
High-performance and stable electrocatalysts for both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) that can work at the same pH condition are highly demanded for the overall water splitting system. Here, we report a partially oxidized Co in suit anchored in a porous nitrogen-doped nano carbon dodecahedron and further its application in electrocatalytic overall water splitting. The Co3O4 shell works as an efficient charge separate functional layer while the metallic Co inner core transport the separated charges immediately to N-carbon framework. By constructing a Schottky barrier between Co3O4 shell and metallic Co core, charge separate/transport process can be speeded up thus the electracatalytic activities dramatically enhanced.
Electrolytic water splitting into hydrogen gas, particularly
driven by renewable clean energy, represents a promising technology for replacing fossil. 1, 2 Hence, high-performance
electrocatalysts for both hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at
cathodes and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at anodes are highly demanded. 3 Currently, Platinum (Pt)-based catalysts have been explored to be most active for HER2, whereas
Ruthenium and Iridium oxides (RuO2, IrO2) are highly efficient for OER.4-7 However, the high cost of noble Pt, Ru and Ir
together with their scarcity on earth have precluded the water
splitting system from cost-effective application in practical.
High performance non-precious metal catalysts for HER or
OER are thus under extensive development in research
community. In particularly, non-precious transition metal sulfides,8-10 phosphides11-13 and oxides14-18 have been
demonstrated as alternative candidates for HER/OER. Most of
the HER catalysts are more active and stable in acidic media than in alkaline conditions.19 However, only IrO2 and RuO2 are active and stable in acidic media for OER.20 This make it difficult to drive overall water splitting efficiently in practical.18
Therefore, it is urgent to develop low-cost, high-performance
bi-functional electrocatalysts to drive the HER and OER
simultaneously.
Recently, cobalt oxides were widely used for catalysts because of the loosely bonded d electrons. 22-26 However, cobalt
oxide particles with poor electronic conductivity facing the low
charge transport between cobalt oxides and electronic conductive framework.27 Charge separation and transport can
be enhanced by constructing a Schottky-barrier between semiconducting metal oxides shell and a metallic core.28
Moreover, catalyst nanoparticles suffer from unstable and
aggregation during catalytic process. Metal-organic framework
(MOF) derived porous carbon support metals or metal oxides
exhibited potential catalytic activity due to its high surface area and porous mass transport pathways.27-29 More importantly,
metals or metal oxides are in suit embedded into carbon
skeleton that avoid aggregation. Currently, MOF-derived
Schottky barriers were applied to fabricate high performance fuel cell catalysts successfully.27, 28 However, to our knowledge,
in situ combination between Schottky barrier and conductive
carbon framework that can catalyze overall water splitting
efficiently has rarely been explored.
Herein, we report a non-precious metal bi-functional catalyst
(Co@Co3O4-NC) derived from Co and N rich MOF via a simple controlled method. Partially oxidized Co nanoparticle
was in situ anchored in N-doped carbon framework under
controlled oxidation conditions. This unique structure strongly
enhanced the charge transport between the nanoparticle and
carbon skeleton, which is quite important for enhancing the
HER/OER activity. As a result, Co@Co3O4-NC performed high

sections.heading: Journal Name COMMUNICATION
sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 2
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
activity with low overpotentials of 221 mV for HER and 391 mV for OER at current density of 10 mA cm-2 in 1 M KOH
aqueous electrolyte. This makes Co@Co3O4-NC a promising alternative catalysts for electrocatalytic overall water splitting.
Fig. 1 a) XRD petterns of Co-NC, Co@Co3O4-NC and Co3O4-NC. b) Raman spectra of Co-NC, Co@Co3O4-NC and Co3O4-NC. c-f) HR-XPS Co 2p, O 1s, N 1s, C1s spectra of Co@Co3O4-NC.
Fig. 2 a) SEM, b) TEM and c) HRTEM images of Co@Co3O4-NC. d) Corresponding elemental mapping.
ZIF-67 was firstly carbonized at 700 ℃ under N2 atmosphere to form composites that Co nanoparticle in situ anchored in
N-doped carbon framework (Co-NC). After a mild oxidation
treatment at 200 ℃ in air with different duration, partially
oxidized Co nanoparticle anchored in N-doped carbon
framework (Co@Co3O4-NC) and fully oxidized Co nanoparticle anchored in N-doped carbon framework
(Co@Co3O4-NC) was formed (see Methods in the Supporting Information for details). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses were
carried out to confirm the designed structure of Co@Co3O4-NC
(Fig. 1a). The diffraction peaks appeared at 44.2 ° and 51.5 °
reflect the (111) and (200) of face-centered (fcc) metallic Co
phase (JCPDS No. 15-0806). At the same time, extra peaks
appeared at 36.9 °, 59.4 ° and 65.2 ° assign to (311), (511) and
(440) of the cubic spinel Co3O4 phase (JCPDS No. 43-1003). The sample Co-NC, obtained without further oxidation
treatment in air, showed diffraction peaks of metallic Co phase
only. The sample Co3O4-NC oxidized longer in air, showed more intense diffraction peaks of cubic spinel Co3O4. Raman spectroscopy of Co@Co3O4-NC clearly figured out the presence of spinel Co3O4 structure at the surface with the typical multi Raman shifts at 482 cm-1, 521 cm-1, 621 cm-1 and 692 cm-1 (Fig. 1b).23 The sample Co-NC showed no Raman
signal at the test range while the sample Co3O4-NC showed more intense Raman shift signal of spinel Co3O4 because of the fully oxidation of metallic Co nanoparticle anchored in carbon
structure with a much longer oxidation duration in air. These
XRD and Raman test results strongly implied that the
controlled sample Co@Co3O4-NC with a structure of partially oxidized Co particle anchored in carbon framework.
X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) survey spectrum of
Co@Co3O4-NC (Fig. S3) revealed that the surface component is mainly consists of C (71.33 at%), N (3.03 at%), Co (8.41
at%) and O (17.24 at%). The high-resolution XPS (HR-XPS) of
Co 2p3/2 spectrum (Fig. 1c) was curve-fitted into typical metallic Co phase at 778.3 eV and Co3O4 at 780.6 eV. 28 Further, the curve-fitted O 1s HR-XPS spectrum confirmed the
presence of O-Co bonding with the typical peak located at 529.9 eV (Fig. 1d).21 The N 1s HR-XPS spectrum (Fig. 1e) was
curve-fitted into three typical types of pyridinic-N (398.9 eV),
graphitic-N (401.2 eV) and oxidized-N (405.6 eV) with a ratio of 37.0 %, 34.8 % and 28.2 %, respectively.30 The C 1s
HR-XPS spectrum (Fig. 1f) clearly showed the typical graphitic
carbon structure (C=C, 284.8 eV) and the presence of doping-N
functional groups (C=N, 285.6 eV). These results matched well
with the designed catalyst structure of partially oxidized Co
particle anchored in nitrogen doped carbon (N-carbon)
skeleton.
Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission
electron microscopy (TEM) were applied to investigate the
morphology of the designed catalyst. The SEM image of
Co@Co3O4-NC (Fig. 2a) showed a regular dodecahedron morphology with an average particle diameter of ca. 300 nm
similar to the primary ZIF-67 caystals, Co-NC and Co3O4-NC (Fig. S4). And plenty of nano particle (Co@Co3O4) with an averge diameter of ca. 20 nm implanted homogeneously in
N-carbon structure. The high-resolution TEM image (HRTEM)
image (Fig. S5), N2 sorption isotherms and the pore size distribution curve (Fig. S6) suggesting the existence of a
micro/meso porous structure. The HRTEM of Co@Co3O4-NC (Fig. 2c) revealed the distinct atomic configuration with a
dihedral angle of 90° and interplanar spacing of 0.242 nm
corresponds to the cubic Co3O4 having (311) lattice fringes around another distinct structure domain with a dihedral angle
of 60° and interplanar spacing of 0.204 nm corresponds to the

Fig. 3 LSVs of Pt/C, Co-NC, Co@Co3O4-NC, Co3O4-NC and IrO2 at 2000 rpm in 1 M KOH with a scanning speed of 2 mV s -1 . a) HER and c) OER
polarization curves. Long-term stability test of Co@Co3O4-NC for b) HER and d) OER before and after 3000 CV cycles at 50 mV s -1 . Catalyst loading:
0.4 mg cm -2 .
fcc metallic Co having (111) lattice fringes.23 Carbon layers
were also clearly figured out around Co@Co3O4 particles. These rusults displayed directly with an expected structure that
partially oxidized Co nanoparticle anchored in carbon.
Corresponding elemental mapping of a single Co@Co3O4-NC dodecahedron (Fig. 2d) supported the conclusion that Co metal
and Co oxide co-exist averagely in the nitrogen functional
groups modified carbon skeleton.
The rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurements were carried out to investigate the electrocatalytic activities of the as-synthesized catalysts compared with the state-of-the-art Pt/C and IrO2 in 1 M KOH aqueous solution. Catalyst were deposited on a glassy carbon disk with a loading of 0.4 mg cm-2. A much higher HER catalytic activity was observed for Co@Co3O4-NC when compared with Co-NC and Co3O4-NC, as indicated by the polarization curves obtained from the linear sweep voltammograms (LSVs). Specifically, the overpotentials required to reach HER current density of 10 mA cm-2 in an order of 221 mV for Co@Co3O4-NC < 263 mV for Co-NC < 357 mV for Co3O4-NC (Fig. 3a). The overpotential for Co@Co3O4-NC makes it comparable to other recently reported high-performance HER catalysts under alkaline media, although it is still inferior to Pt/C. Meanwhile, Co@Co3O4-NC presented a lower Tafel slope (77.3 mV dec−1 ) than Co-NC (157.4 mV dec−1 ) and Co3O4-NC (240.2 mV dec −1 ), indicating a faster HER kinetic process (Fig. S7a). A good stable performance for Co@Co3O4-NC under HER testing conditions was implied by the slight shift of the LSV polarization curve after 3000 cyclic sweep voltammogram (CV) cycles. The overpotential required to reach 10 mA cm-2 increased slightly from 221 mV to 225 mV (Fig. 3b). A similar activity trend was observed during the OER tests for Co@Co3O4-NC, Co-NC and Co3O4-NC. The overpotentials required to reach OER current density of 10 mA cm-2 in an order of 282 mV for IrO2 < 391 mV for
Fig. 4 a) A digital photograph of the home-made two-electrode water splitting and gas collection device. b) Polarization curves of Co@Co3O4-NC ǁ Co@Co3O4-NC, Pt/C ǁ IrO2, Pt/C ǁ Pt/C and IrO2 ǁ IrO2. c) Long-term stability test of Co@Co3O4-NC before and after 3000 CV cycles at 50 mV s -1 . d) Volume of generated H2 and O2 at a constant potential of 2 V.
Catalyst loading: 0.5 mg cm -2 for HER and 1.5 mg cm -2 for OER.
Co@Co3O4-NC < 411 mV for Co3O4-NC < 421 mV forCo-NC (Fig. 3c). In addition, Co@Co3O4-NC presented a lower Tafel slope (102.8 mV dec−1 ) than Co-NC (109.9 mV dec−1 ) and Co3O4-NC (103.6 mV dec−1 ), indicating a faster OER kinetic process (Fig.
S7b). A good stable performance for Co@Co3O4-NC under OER testing conditions was implied by the slight shift of the LSV polarization curve after 3000 CV cycles. The overpotential required to reach 10 mA cm-2 increased slightly from 391 mV to 394 mV (Fig. 3d). From the comparison of the HER/OER performance of Co@Co3O4-NC, Co-NC and Co3O4-NC, the benefit of partially oxidized Co particle structure catalyst revealed. The Co3O4 shell works as efficient charge separate functional layer while the metallic Co inner core transport the separated charges much more efficient than fully oxidized Co3O4 to N-carbon framework. The unique structure enhances the charge separate/transport speed thus enhances the electrocatalytic activities dramatically.
Since Co@Co3O4-NC performed as a high performance and stable bi-functional catalyst toward both OER and HER, we
constructed a two-electrode cell for over water splitting in 1 M
KOH aqueous solution, where Co@Co3O4-NC deposited on nickle foam (1cm * 1cm) was used as both anode and cathode.
The anode and cathode were separated by a piece of
ion-exchange membrane. For comparison, Pt/C ǁ Pt/C, IrO2 ǁ IrO2 and Pt/C ǁ IrO2 were also tested. The required cell voltage to reach a current density of 10 mA cm-2 in an order of 1.752 V
for Pt/C ǁ IrO2 < 2.004 V for Co@Co3O4-NC ǁ Co@Co3O4-NC < 2.348 for Pt/C ǁ Pt/C < 2.494 for IrO2 ǁ IrO2 (Fig. 4b). Only a 250 mV range for Co@Co3O4-NC ǁ Co@Co3O4-NC higher than state-of-the-art precious Pt/C ǁ IrO2 system. The cell voltage only slightly increases from 2.004 to 2.025 V to achieve 10 mA

cm-2 after 3000 CV cycles under overall water splitting
conditions (Fig. 4c). Further, a constant cell voltage of 2 V was
provided for a Co@Co3O4-NC ǁ Co@Co3O4-NC drived cell where the current density reached to 10 mA cm-2 in 1 M KOH.
While generated H2 and O2 were collected by a simple home-made device (Fig. 4a). The volume ratio of collected H2 and O2 approaching to the theoretical value of 2:1 during the electrolysis (Fig. 4d). These results make Co@Co3O4-NC as a promising bi-functional electrocatalysts for overall water
splitting in alkaline media.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we successfully constructed a composite
structure that partially oxidized Co nanoparticles anchored in
N-doped carbon regular dodecahedron frameworks
(Co@Co3O4-NC) via a MOF-routed method. The Co3O4 shell works as efficient charge separate functional layer while the
metallic Co inner core transport the separated charges
immediately to N-carbon framework. Owing to its unique
structure, the charge separate/transport process can be speeded
up thus the electrocatalytic activity dramatically enhanced. As a
result, Co@Co3O4-NC was demonstrated to be a bi-functional HER/OER eletrocatalyst with excellent activity and stability
that outperformed single Pt or IrO2 electrodes. This together with its element abundant and facile fabricate method, makes
Co@Co3O4-NC as a promising electrocatalyst for overall water splitting system in alkaline media.

sections.text:
